answers.answer: I have many patients who do fine post-RAI and the hypothyroidism is well treated and tolerated.Any method of treating hyper usually causes some weight gain as the thyroid-related-metabolism is falsely elevated during hyper and then is brought back to normal.Thyroid specialists are endocrinologists who have dedicated their practice in large part to thyroid conditions rather than other endocrine conditions like diabetes.  The choice or RAI vs ATD varies from specialist to specialist.   Recent data on 10 year use of ATD suggest this is safe if closely monitored and the patient is responding well.  RAI or surgery is my back-up plan if ATD treatment is not going well.....

Dr. Lupo I do appreciate your time in answering my question and assuaging my fears in the regards of the ATD option of treating my hyperthyroidism, I have a good few years I can take this route for.So how do I got about finding out if the endo that I am going to is a thyroid specialist, do I check for different abbrevations to make sure thier title does not include the diabetes portion of their training? It seems that one or two endo's I went to I feel like I can't ask any questions and they seem very desensitized  by all these thyroid issues, treating my reports like a text book case, it's very disheartening to me.-Gilda741

diabetes is part of all endocrine training -  and >90% of endo's have a >70% diabetes practice -- leaving less time for thyroid.....would look at thyroidologists.com or thyroid.org -- these are mostly thyroid-focused endocrinologists.560 for a consultation!  I hope that included labs and ultrasound and at least 40 minutes of time -- I should not comment on that, but it is a reflection of a flawed healthcare system....

You seem petrified of the RAI treatment.  I had it 12 years ago and they must have hit it perfectly because I was normal for all this time.  No side effects and just recently my numbers are going up again.  I may have to take meds or do the RAI again.  We shall see.  I was wondering like you can we hyperthyroid people just stay the way we are and do nothing?  What would happen?Lisa at ***@****

They (endo's) have the only one way to scare patients and that's by telling them RAI is theonly way unless you want to die, some endo's have the audacity to instigate fear like that.But there was another poster in the patient to patient forum where a poster named annag966 put a somewhat of a pro's and con's list that I just read and it pretty much helped me make and stick to my decision of taking ATD's to treat my Graves. I had the RAI, really didn't understand the options.  Ended up with all the things that could happen to you afterward although it didn't happen for almost 9 months and before I knew what it was over a year.  I thought my symptoms were caused by something else not my thyroid.  I went through a horrible 6 months but with the guidence of the Lord and my doctors I am coming through it and expect to come out ok.   I don't know if I made the right decision or not but it seems like it is ending up ok.  I guess I will be posting on this forum for a while as I recover from the hypothyroidism.  I will be interested to follow your postings to see how you make out and what recommendations you find to not have it done.   praying for the best for your,  lol linda

I had RAI in Feb.,05. That was the only choice I was given by my physican. I asked abou t surgery instead & I was told it was too dangerous. I was in no shape to shop around for other doctors...my TSH was not detectable & my T-4 was 3x's normal. I was informed of  the precautions following the treatment but not the possible side effects short term or long term. I have had some major problems with thyroid eye disease. Would this have happened with ATD's? I'll never know? But with ATD's there is a chance that your thyroid could recover without losing complete function as you do with RAI. In my opinion, ATD's are worth a try, if you can tolerate the medicine.  It's alittle more work for you & the doctor has to monitor you closer but it's personal preference & your body.  There are some who have had no problem with RAI but no one should be forced into something they do not want you have the right to refuse.Good Luck & God Bless,TJ

I guess it's a little too late for me now (about 6hrs). Just had RAI today because the doctors told me that was my "best" option for my toxic nodular goitre. I was also told that it would get bigger down the road, and my only option then would be surgery(hated the thoughts of that one even more). I had a bit of a problem with my eyes but nothing drastic, just a bit of swelling, which was the way I even discovered I was hyper.  Like I just said---too late for me now and I'm sure praying for a good outcome. By the way, my aunt had the RAI 18 years ago, she is still alive and well and skinnier than she was as a teenager. They have been doing this RAI for over 50 years now, you can't say that about a lot of the medications that are on the market today---they're taking stuff off the shelf everyday for some medical reason or another.  That's kind of scary too.  Good luck in your decision, and good luck for mine too.
